subject: design: Add multi-host support in ipmid and ipmbbridged
commitMessage:
design: Add multi-host support in ipmid and ipmbbridged

Multi host design proposal for ipmi commands handling

Signed-off-by: Velumani Thangavel <velumanit@hcl.com>
Change-Id: I99ca26d94f5f33d1af6c02820a915c9202df8901

The host id details are explained in the line numbers 76 to 82

**Change: Sending Host detail as additional parameter**

While routing the IPMB requests coming from the host channel, We will be
adding new entry in the json config file for the host ID '"devIndex": 0'
ipmbbridged will send '"devIndex": 0' as optional parameter(options) in D-Bus
interface to ipmid.This can be used to get the information on which IPMB bus
the message comes from.

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 0344dc18f0ff8d1b709366d34881f0501d565d25 by Patrick Williams
Its a convention to wrap design document at 80 characters so that it is easier to review. Can you please wrap it to 80 chars ?
Thanks for your comments, Addressed this comment.

ipmb? Also suggesting to reword this as:
"The outgoing ipmb requests are routed by ipmbbridged".
Updated as per the comment.
nitpick: empty space
Done

Why is it that we are adding additional parameter ? This won't be a common parameter for all ipmb consumers, no? (Example ME/Add-in-cards with IPMB support etc.)

Would it be advantageous to have a new type called "host-ipmb-1" ? You can parse the suffixes to know host IPMB instance.
This approach is suggested by Vernon to add host as additional parameter. This can be used for identifying ipmb bus information for any ipmb interface (ME/IPMB/addon card etc).
How would this be handled ?
Updated the impacts section.
What are the IPMI commands that needs to process host specific response?
There are many oem commands specific to the Host, for example DIMM infor, POST code buffer for a host, Processor info etc.

For netipmid, there are separate instances of netipmid daemon for each ethernet interface. So thinking if there should be multiple instances of IpmbBridged for each ipmb* VS a single IpmbBridged design mentioned here. Please add some details why we have picked up this choice.
I don't recall what reasons were cited when the ipmbbridged was created. I would be fine if they were split apart.

We tried using separate instances of ipmbbridged, each instance will have a ipmi channel assigned. There are 2 things considered, 1. only 8 channels can be configured not more than that. 2. Running multiple instances with no advantage, single instance with the config file does the same.
Is that because of available ipmi channels in the ipmi spec? This may be something we need to work around as well, possibly with some virtualization of hosts/channels.
Yes. We can have a work around of '"host:" 1' as we are proposing in single instance can be used for multi-process as well. Let me know your thoughts.
`"host" : 1`
Done
`"host" : 1`
Done

How are RMCP+ commands differentiating what host? Are they to use LUN? If so, maybe ipmbbridged should use LUN as well?

If not, then what? It would be nice to be able to use a common mechanism.

We have addressed only the in-band ipmi communication with this design. Can we take up the out of band little later?

I dont think LUNs can be used as we have only 4 LUNs and 2 is already assigned for BMC and SMIC. only remaining 2 can be used and that wont be sufficient for multi-host.
I think if you are going to do it right, you will need to address them together. I don't want a piecemeal solution to such a complex problem.
Thanks for your input, I am working on this comment.

Hi Vernon, I have analyzed the RMCP+ commands, We will be able to use the same design proposed for ipmb channels for RMCP+ as well. The "options" parameter can be used for sending the host information. There will not be further changes required in ipmid. The net-ipmid can have multiple approaches to handle multi host Like 1. Virtual Ethernet interfaces - One virtual interface per host. 2. Different port numbers - Can have different port numbers for each host. 3. VLAN Id- VLAN IDs can be used to support multi host. Please suggest shall we proceed on ipmbbridged and ipmid changes.
The final patchset is missing the details of how the network IPMI will handle the host information.
Updated in the latest patch-set.

The Get/Set system boot options command has the Set selector/Block selector, should that be used to differentiate the different boot settings for each host. My point is that if the command has a mechanism already why invent another mechanism.

The set selector is to choose which item, while the block selector is to choose which block within that item for large items. It has nothing to do with multiple host support.

I don't think IPMI was ever designed to handle this sort of host aggregation. There is also LUN in every command, but that only goes to 4, which could limit high-density multi-host situations.

Requiring the hosts to do something special (pass an ID or LUN or whatever) for every command seems like it could break things. If the ID is already implicitly encoded in the link the command was received on, why not use that?

Sorry for the confusion here, I did not mean the Get/Set system boot option. There is a different oem command to get/set boot sequence of individual host. Each host information is stored in a different array in BMC. Based on which host is requesting the data will be fetched and responded from BMC.

LUN? multiple instances of ipmid? Please do some discovery in these areas.

Surely there were other alternatives considered. If you have not considered any other alternatives, it is hard to convince oneself that this is the best solution.
We have considered other alternative approches as well. I Will update the details.
Updated the alternatives

According to our test for multi-host ipmibridge comunication, 
1. every Hosts set its slave address as "bmc-addr": 32, so the remote-addr would be 32. what does "remote-addr": 64 used for?
2. And ipmi driver(ipmb_dev_int()) is used "bmc-addr": 32 for ipmb header checksum in "if (is_ipmb_msg(ipmb_dev, GET_8BIT_ADDR(client->addr)))" of ipmb_slave_cb(), if it's "remote-addr": 64, it could not pass the checksum verification here and the ipmb package would be discarded.
So, the bmc-addr and remote-addr should be the same one for the peer-peer host to host ipmb communication. Please correct me.

IPMB communication is based on Request and response. The requester has a slave address and responder can have a different slave address. In our case when the request goes from BMC to host, "bmc-addr" is a requester slave address(rsSA) and "remote-addr" is a responder slave address (rqSA) which is a host. I think this answers your question.

OK, do you mean "Host" is "CPU Host", and multi-host is Multi CPU host? not multi-BMC communication?
if that's the case, could you add BMC in the "IPMI and IPMB System architecture"? and the only One BMC in the "IPMI and IPMB System architecture" is in Ipmbbridged? thanks.

Sure. I have added BMC in the architecture. 
Regarding the Host, yes you are right it is a CPU host. The case is we have one BMC and multiple CPU hosts connected in ipmb interface.
Is it possible to add test steps/description here?
Yes. I will be adding test steps/description.
Added test description.
nit:OpenBMC
Done
nit: upper case IPMI
Done
nit: uppercase IPMB
Done
If no standard commands are involved and only OEM commands are going to handle host specific information.We can make a mention of that in this document.

The standard commands also needs a host specific responses. Few example are
1. Power restore policy. This will be a host specific response. BMC should maintain data for each host separately and send the response based on which host requesting.
2. SEL - System event logs is an another example of host specific. 
3. WDT - Watchdog set/get requests.
nit: ipmbbridged
Done
The intent of this is not clear to me.
The IPMB requests can be sent from ipmid or any other service running in BMC using d-bus method call "sendRequest". This is to explain the architecture.
A blank line before ##Requirements
Done
nit:D-Bus
Done
nit:ipmbbridged
Done
nit: BMC upper case
Done
Do you forsee any standard command handler to handle provide data based on the host id?

The standard commands also needs a host specific responses. Few example are
1. Power restore policy. This will be a host specific response. BMC should maintain data for each host separately and send the response based on which host requesting.
2. SEL - System event logs is an another example of host specific. 
3. WDT - Watchdog set/get requests.
Does that mean in the IPMI command data?
Yes, This will affect the existing implementation and deviate the specification as well.
major
Done
running
Done
Is there an impact on the existing command handlers?
I think there is no impact in the existing handlers. For the multi host we will register a override handlers with the context parameter. As the context parameter is already exists there is no impact.
rephrase
done

I think this update does not answer how the host details can be passed via the IPMI LAN Messaging. The suggestion from Vernon is whether we can use LUN in the IPMI LAN packet to pass the host information. You seem to focus on adapting netipmid to fit the multi host scenario, which is probably not needed.

Thanks for your review and your comments.

As we responded in the earlier comment I do not think LUNs can be used as we have only 4 LUNs and 2 is already assigned for BMC and SMIC. only remaining 2 can be used and that wont be sufficient for multi-host.

As per my understanding netipmid is the bridge for all IPMI LAN packets, So proposing a design with netipmid. This design is similar to the ipmbbrige where we use a ipmb bus Id to get the host details. In the same manner the netipmid can get the host details from any one of the listed approaches. Please let me know if I am missing something.

> As we responded in the earlier comment I do not think LUNs can be used as we have only 4 LUNs and 2 is already assigned for BMC and SMIC. only remaining 2 can be used and that wont be sufficient for multi-host.

Thanks for clarifying that LUN does not fit your usecase. 

> As per my understanding netipmid is the bridge for all IPMI LAN packets, So proposing a design with netipmid. This design is similar to the ipmbbrige where we use a ipmb bus Id to get the host details. In the same manner the netipmid can get the host details from any one of the listed approaches. Please let me know if I am missing something.

netipmid instances are run typically per ethernet interface. Do you mean to run different instances of netipmid? If so, how does each instance forward host information to the ipmi daemon? 

Atleast for me this section is vague, it will need a block diagram and some more details on how the host information is forwarded by netipmid (instance/instances) to ipmid just like how ipmbbridged forwards the host specific information to ipmi daemon.
Updated a netipmid approach with a diagram.

I am not sure we should rely on the N in the vethN. Is there something that we can do to the channel config file to be more explicit here?

would it be possible, for example to have two NICs per host?

Thanks Vernon for your review and the comments. This is a good idea to have a config file where in we can configure what is the interface and it belongs to which host. The interface can be a physical or virtual.

I think it is possible to have two (or more) network interfaces per host. The config file needs to be flexible to support more than one interface per host.

We can have a config file for the netipmid with the following example. Please let me know your thoughts on this.

{ "Host": "1",
"Interface-1": "eth0",
"Interface-2": "eth1",
"Interface-3": "veth4",
"Interface-4": "veth5"
},
{ "Host": "2",
"Interface-1": "eth2",
"Interface-2": "eth3",
"Interface-3": "veth1",
"Interface-4": "veth2"
},
Done
